G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4 and G.L. c. 214, \.proposition: 4. This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 214, § 1, because Plaintiff seeks legal and equitable relief for common-law negligence, and the amount in controversy exceeds the jurisdictional minimum of the District Court and is appropriate for the Superior Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1 and \u00a7 2.proposition: 5. Venue is proper in Hampden County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and § 2, because the cause of action arose in Hampden County and both Plaintiff and Defendant reside in Hampden County.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.proposition: 28. Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses elements of negligence, particularly the need to prove breach of duty, causation, and damages, but it does not articulate a general, overarching Massachusetts rule that "every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property." The court instead assumes arguendo that a duty may exist and resolves the case on lack of causation and proof of defect. Thus, it is not authority for the broad duty proposition stated.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: 28. Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The court explicitly states a general rule of Massachusetts tort law that "every actor" has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, grounded in foreseeability. While the opinion’s facts involve firearms and focus on physical injury rather than property damage, the articulated principle is a broad, general duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm, which aligns with the proposition (even though the opinion does not separately discuss property harm).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: 29. Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care arising from, among other things: a. Their relationship as neighboring occupants sharing a common driveway at 123 Elm Street; b. Defendant’s ownership, possession, and control of the ladder; and c. Defendant’s creation and maintenance of a condition (an unsecured, tall ladder leaning against a fence adjacent to the driveway) that posed an unreasonable and foreseeable risk of harm to Plaintiff’s vehicle.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a duty of reasonable care based on a neighboring relationship, control of a ladder, and creation of a hazardous condition on a shared driveway. Davis v. Westwood Group deals with a commercial landowner’s duty regarding a public highway and whether it must provide a pedestrian bridge or signal; it does not involve neighboring occupants, shared driveways, or dangerous instrumentalities like ladders. While the case restates the general rule that landowners owe reasonable care to lawful visitors, its specific holding actually limits, rather than expands, duties based on ownership/control of adjacent property and thus does not provide authority for the detailed duty alleged here.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. … Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.”

Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.proposition: 29. Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care arising from, among other things: a. Their relationship as neighboring occupants sharing a common driveway at 123 Elm Street; b. Defendant’s ownership, possession, and control of the ladder; and c. Defendant’s creation and maintenance of a condition (an unsecured, tall ladder leaning against a fence adjacent to the driveway) that posed an unreasonable and foreseeable risk of harm to Plaintiff’s vehicle.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that a defendant owed a plaintiff a duty of reasonable care based on neighboring status, control of a ladder, and creation of a hazardous condition. Luoni v. Berube concerns social host liability and the duty (or lack thereof) of homeowners regarding fireworks brought and used by third-party guests. The court in Luoni emphasizes no duty where the defendants did not provide, control, or create the dangerous condition; it does not address shared driveways, control of a ladder, or duties regarding an unsecured object posing risk to a neighbor’s vehicle, and its reasoning tends to cut against expanding duties in analogous situations.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The common bond between the decisions involving social host liability for alcohol-related injuries, and the circumstances here, is the fact that the defendants did not provide the harmful item, did not control its use, and did not create the situation that caused the danger. … [N]o person owes to another a duty to prevent the harmful consequences of a condition or situation he or she did not create.” 431 Mass. at 733–34 (internal citation omitted).

These repeated warnings placed Defendant.raw_text: These repeated warnings placed Defendant on actual notice of the specific risk that ultimately materialized. See Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 61 (1983) (foreseeability supported by prior warnings and notice); Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–106 (1978) (duty informed by actual knowledge of potential hazard).
These repeated warnings placed Defendant.proposition: 32. These repeated warnings placed Defendant on actual notice of the specific risk that ultimately materialized.
These repeated warnings placed Defendant.support_reasoning: The cited text is from a dissent in Mullins and is focused almost entirely on proximate cause and foreseeability in a premises-liability context, not on whether repeated warnings gave the defendant actual notice of a specific risk. The dissent critiques the majority’s causation analysis; it does not discuss prior warnings, notice, or actual knowledge as a basis for liability. Thus, this excerpt does not support the proposition that repeated warnings placed the defendant on actual notice of the particular risk that materialized.
These repeated warnings placed Defendant.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969)."

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 61 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: 32. These repeated warnings placed Defendant on actual notice of the specific risk that ultimately materialized.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The dissenting excerpt focuses on proximate causation, sufficiency of evidence, and foreseeability concerning campus security measures and the rape, not on whether prior or repeated warnings gave the defendant actual notice of a specific risk. There is no discussion of any series of warnings or notice to the defendant about the particular risk that materialized. Therefore, this opinion does not support the proposition that repeated warnings placed the defendant on actual notice of the specific risk.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–106 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: 32. These repeated warnings placed Defendant on actual notice of the specific risk that ultimately materialized.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses foreseeability and the defendant’s knowledge of a general risk (intoxicated seamen and unsecured forklifts), not repeated warnings that would amount to actual notice of the specific risk that materialized. There is no mention of prior complaints, incidents, or warnings given to the defendant about this precise danger. Thus, the case supports a theory of foreseeable risk based on circumstances and known patterns, not actual notice through repeated warnings.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt:
“The authority was aware that intoxicated seamen frequented the area, and it was also aware that social guests of officers or crew members routinely visited the ships in port.

It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen who the authority knew had unfettered access to the cargo area.”

Defendant\u2019s failure to take any suc.raw_text: Defendant’s failure to take any such precautionary measures constitutes a breach of his duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts negligence law. See Jupin, 447 Mass. at 147–149 (owner’s duty to secure dangerous instrumentalities when risk of harm to others is foreseeable); Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629–30 (1989) (duty extends to risks that are reasonably foreseeable).
Defendant\u2019s failure to take any suc.proposition: 36. Defendant’s failure to take any such precautionary measures constitutes a breach of his duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts negligence law.
Defendant\u2019s failure to take any suc.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that a defendant’s failure to take precautionary measures constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts negligence law. In Yakubowicz, the SJC recognizes that Paramount and Saxon owed a general duty of reasonable care, but then holds as a matter of law that they did not violate that duty, largely because their conduct was protected by the First Amendment and because the harm was too remote. The opinion does not state or suggest that failure to take additional precautions in these circumstances constituted a breach; instead it rejects liability, so it does not support the proposition.
Defendant\u2019s failure to take any suc.relevant_excerpt:
In keeping with that principle, Paramount and Saxon owed a duty of reasonable care to members of the public including the plaintiff’s decedent with respect to the producing, exhibiting, and advertising of movies.

The next question is whether there is a genuine issue with respect to whether that duty was violated. With reference to counts one, two, and four of the plaintiff’s complaint alleging negligence in the creation and exhibition of “The Warriors,” we conclude that, as a matter of law, the defendants did not violate their duty of reasonable care.

Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.raw_text: Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629–30 (1989)
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.proposition: 36. Defendant’s failure to take any such precautionary measures constitutes a breach of his duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts negligence law.
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that Paramount and Saxon owed a duty of reasonable care to the public, but it explicitly holds that, on these facts, they did not violate that duty; it does not state that a failure to take particular precautionary measures constitutes a breach. Instead, the court concludes that First Amendment protections and the absence of a cognizable causal/duty link preclude liability. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that a defendant’s failure to take precautionary measures is, in itself, a breach of duty under Massachusetts negligence law.
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.relevant_excerpt:
“In keeping with that principle, Paramount and Saxon owed a duty of reasonable care to members of the public including the plaintiff’s decedent with respect to the producing, exhibiting, and advertising of movies.

The next question is whether there is a genuine issue with respect to whether that duty was violated. With reference to counts one, two, and four of the plaintiff’s complaint… we conclude that, as a matter of law, the defendants did not violate their duty of reasonable care.”

The danger that in fact occurred\u2014th.raw_text: The danger that in fact occurred—the ladder being blown over by wind and striking Plaintiff’s vehicle—was a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s negligent conduct and was precisely the type of harm that made Defendant’s conduct unreasonable. See Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 640–642 (1996) (foreseeability of general type of harm suffices); Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454–455 (1969).
The danger that in fact occurred\u2014th.proposition: 37. The danger that in fact occurred—the ladder being blown over by wind and striking Plaintiff’s vehicle—was a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s negligent conduct and was precisely the type of harm that made Defendant’s conduct unreasonable.
The danger that in fact occurred\u2014th.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
The danger that in fact occurred\u2014th.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence in Poskus criticizing the majority’s treatment of prior causation cases and simply agreeing that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm. The text does not state or endorse the specific proposition that the harm was a natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s conduct or that it was the type of harm that made the conduct unreasonable. Instead, it indicates the opposite conclusion on foreseeability in that case, so this excerpt does not support the claimed ladder proposition.
The danger that in fact occurred\u2014th.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the view that "[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence." Ante at 640-641.

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 640–642 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: 37. The danger that in fact occurred—the ladder being blown over by wind and striking Plaintiff’s vehicle—was a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s negligent conduct and was precisely the type of harm that made Defendant’s conduct unreasonable.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence explicitly agrees with the majority that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. The proposition asserts that the particular harm (the ladder being blown over and striking the vehicle) was a natural, probable, and precisely foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s conduct. That is the opposite of what Justice Lynch concurs in; he endorses the conclusion that the injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk, so the case does not support the proposition.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.raw_text: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454–455 (1969)
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.proposition: 37. The danger that in fact occurred—the ladder being blown over by wind and striking Plaintiff’s vehicle—was a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s negligent conduct and was precisely the type of harm that made Defendant’s conduct unreasonable.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.case_name: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The case deals with a bar’s liability for a shooting by a drunk patron and the foreseeability of violence in that context, not with a ladder being blown over or similar property-damage scenarios. While the opinion does discuss foreseeability and proximate cause, it does so in the context of assaults by intoxicated patrons, not the specific type of harm described in the proposition; thus it cannot be cited as authority that the wind-blown-ladder incident was the natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s negligence. The proposition mischaracterizes both the facts and the type of harm considered in Carey.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: The defendant could not be held liable unless the injury was a foreseeable consequence of the act or failure to act, if there was such failure or such negligent act. There must be a proximate causal relationship to hold the defendant responsible. The specific kind of harm need not be foreseeable as long as it was foreseeable that there would be harm from the act which constituted the negligence, provided it was foreseeable that there would be violence toward others. If the jury concluded that the shooting was such a remote possibility that it constituted an intervening cause of harm, their verdict should be for the defendant.

But for Defendant\u2019s negligent stora.raw_text: But for Defendant’s negligent storage and failure to secure the ladder, the ladder would not have fallen and Plaintiff’s vehicle would not have been damaged. See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320 (2002) (proximate cause where negligent conduct is substantial contributing factor in bringing about harm).
But for Defendant\u2019s negligent stora.proposition: 38. But for Defendant’s negligent storage and failure to secure the ladder, the ladder would not have fallen and Plaintiff’s vehicle would not have been damaged.
But for Defendant\u2019s negligent stora.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts a straightforward but-for causation statement in a typical negligence property-damage scenario. Kent v. Commonwealth concerns proximate (legal) cause in a complex public-entity, parole, and intervening-superseding-cause context, and ultimately holds that the earlier negligent act is not the proximate cause of the later injury. While the opinion discusses both factual and proximate causation in general terms, it does not establish or apply a "but for" test in the simple manner claimed, nor does it involve negligent storage of objects or vehicle damage, so it does not meaningfully support this specific proposition.
But for Defendant\u2019s negligent stora.relevant_excerpt: “[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff… In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. … Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: 38. But for Defendant’s negligent storage and failure to secure the ladder, the ladder would not have fallen and Plaintiff’s vehicle would not have been damaged.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a straightforward “but for” causation statement in an ordinary negligence context involving a ladder and property damage. Kent v. Commonwealth addresses proximate cause, superseding cause, and governmental immunity in the context of a parole decision leading to a later shooting, not the causal relationship between negligent storage of a ladder and falling damage. The opinion does not discuss ladders, negligent storage of personal property, or the specific type of but‑for causation claimed, so it does not provide authority for that proposition.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff… In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well… Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.” (Kent, 437 Mass. at 320-321).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: 40. Even if the Court were to find that Plaintiff bore some degree of comparative negligence, which Plaintiff expressly denies, Plaintiff would still be entitled to recover under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, so long as any negligence attributable to Plaintiff is not greater than the negligence attributable to Defendant, and any such recovery would be reduced in proportion to Plaintiff’s percentage of fault.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: 41. Under G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to interest on any damages awarded for property damage from the date this action is commenced.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85; Hopkins v. Medei.raw_text: G.L. c. 231, § 85; Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 600, 602–604 (2000)
G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85; Hopkins v. Medei.proposition: 43. Plaintiff did not incur medical bills or lose wages as a result of the incident; however, Massachusetts negligence law permits recovery for property damage, loss of use, and consequential economic losses proximately caused by a defendant’s breach of duty.
G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85; Hopkins v. Medei.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses duty, the rescue doctrine, and the firefighter’s rule, and cites G.L. c. 41 §§100, 111F and c. 231 §85 only in the context of assumption of risk and police officers’ ability to sue tortfeasors. It does not address categories of recoverable damages such as property damage, loss of use, or consequential economic losses when there are no medical bills or lost wages. Thus it provides no authority for the specific damages proposition asserted.
G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85; Hopkins v. Medei.relevant_excerpt:
Primary assumption is thus distinguished from “secondary” assumption of the risk. The affirmative defense of secondary assumption of the risk has been abolished by statute in Massachusetts. See G. L. c. 231, § 85.

In Massachusetts, police officers are excluded from the workers’ compensation statutes, G. L. c. 152, § 69, but instead receive injury-related benefits under similar statutes. They receive leave with pay under G. L. c. 41, § 111F, and payment for their medical expenses under G. L. c. 41, § 100.

Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.raw_text: Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 600, 602–604 (2000)
Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.proposition: 43. Plaintiff did not incur medical bills or lose wages as a result of the incident; however, Massachusetts negligence law permits recovery for property damage, loss of use, and consequential economic losses proximately caused by a defendant’s breach of duty.
Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns duty, the rescue doctrine, and the firefighter’s rule, not the scope of recoverable negligence damages. It does not discuss categories of damages such as medical bills, wage loss, property damage, loss of use, or consequential economic loss, nor does it state that recovery is permitted where the plaintiff has no medical or wage loss. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific damages proposition claimed.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: D. Award Plaintiff her taxable costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable rules of civil procedure, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
